figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Awareness of age-related change (AARC) gains-to-losses ratio in community-dwelling and institutionalized older adults across age groups.

claims.sentence: However, the gains-to-losses balance was positive for younger age groups and only flipped toward a dominance of losses for those beyond the age of 90 (see also Figure 1).

Open in a new tab
Awareness of age-related change (AARC) gains-to-losses ratio in community-dwelling and institutionalized older adults across age groups.As expected, individuals in long-term care settings reported significantly lower levels of perceived gains and higher levels of losses compared to individuals in private homes (Table 1 and Figure 1).
Examination of confidence bands for estimated age effects across the continuum of moderator values provided additional insights (Supplementary Figure 3, left column).

For functional health and autonomy, concurrent AARC-Gains buffered the adverse effect of AARC-Losses, whereas the latter increased the impact of concurrent AARC-Gains on these late-life functioning outcomes (Supplementary Figure 3, right column).
However, the gains-to-losses balance was positive for younger age groups and only flipped toward a dominance of losses for those beyond the age of 90 (see also Figure 1).

Open in a new tab

For functional health and autonomy, concurrent AARC-Gains buffered the adverse effect of AARC-Losses, whereas the latter increased the impact of concurrent AARC-Gains on these late-life functioning outcomes (Supplementary Figure 3, right column).
However, the gains-to-losses balance was positive for younger age groups and only flipped toward a dominance of losses for those beyond the age of 90 (see also Figure 1).

Awareness of age-related change (AARC) gains-to-losses ratio in community-dwelling and institutionalized older adults across age groups.As expected, individuals in long-term care settings reported significantly lower levels of perceived gains and higher levels of losses compared to individuals in private homes (Table 1 and Figure 1).
However, the gains-to-losses balance was positive for younger age groups and only flipped toward a dominance of losses for those beyond the age of 90 (see also Figure 1).
As expected, individuals in long-term care settings reported significantly lower levels of perceived gains and higher levels of losses compared to individuals in private homes (Table 1 and Figure 1).
Examination of confidence bands for estimated age effects across the continuum of moderator values provided additional insights (Supplementary Figure 3, left column).

For functional health and autonomy, concurrent AARC-Gains buffered the adverse effect of AARC-Losses, whereas the latter increased the impact of concurrent AARC-Gains on these late-life functioning outcomes (Supplementary Figure 3, right column).
Examination of confidence bands for estimated age effects across the continuum of moderator values provided additional insights (Supplementary Figure 3, left column).

For functional health and autonomy, concurrent AARC-Gains buffered the adverse effect of AARC-Losses, whereas the latter increased the impact of concurrent AARC-Gains on these late-life functioning outcomes (Supplementary Figure 3, right column).
